title: How to Cook Escarole and Bean Soup

methods.name: Making Simple Escarole and Bean Soup

steps.headline: Sauté the garlic.
steps.description: Pour 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of olive oil into a saucepan. Turn the stove on to medium heat and wait for the oil to get hot. Add the chopped garlic cloves and sauté them for 15 seconds.

steps.headline: Add the escarole.
steps.description: Continue sautéing it until it wilts. This will take about 2 minutes.

steps.headline: Season it with salt, then add the chicken broth, beans, and Parmesan cheese.
steps.description: How much salt you add is entirely up to you; the more you add, the saltier the soup will be.

steps.headline: Simmer the soup, covered, for about 5 minutes.
steps.description: Bring the soup to a boil over medium to medium-high heat. As soon as the soup starts to boil, reduce the soup to low. Cover the saucepan with a lid and let the soup simmer for 5 minutes. It's ready when the beans are heated all the way through.

steps.headline: Season the soup further, if needed.
steps.description: Give the soup a taste, then add some more salt and pepper, if necessary. Another option would be to serve the soup as is, and allow the guests to season the soup further to their personal tastes.

steps.headline: Serve the soup with extra-virgin olive oil.
steps.description: Ladle the soup into serving bowls. Drizzle 1 teaspoon of extra-virgin olive oil over each bowl. Serve the soup while it is hot. This soup tastes great with a piece of crusty bread on the side.

methods.name: Making Gourmet Escarole and Bean Soup

steps.headline: Sauté the pancetta for five minutes.
steps.description: Pour 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of olive oil into a saucepan. Turn the heat up to medium and let the oil get hot. Cut the pancetta into ¼-inch (0.64-centimeter) cubes and add it to the pot. Sauté it for 5 minutes. If you can't find any pancetta, you can use prosciutto instead.

steps.headline: Set the pancetta aside.
steps.description: Use a slotted spoon to remove the pancetta from the saucepan. Set the pancetta aside on a plate. Leave the oil in the saucepan.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion.
steps.description: Chop up the onion and add it to the saucepan. Sauté it until it turns golden in color. This will take about 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Add the garlic, rosemary, and red pepper flakes.
steps.description: Continue sautéing for 3 more minutes. If you can't find any rosemary, you can use thyme instead.

steps.headline: Add the escarole.
steps.description: Continue cooking everything for 2 minutes. Stir the mixture often with a wooden spoon or rubber spatula.

steps.headline: Add the beans, tomato, broth, and salt.
steps.description: Give the mixture a good stir, then bring it to a boil over medium to medium-high heat. It is best if you use vine-ripened tomatoes. If you can't find any, use chopped canned plum tomatoes instead; be sure to drain them first, however.

steps.headline: Simmer the soup, covered, for 10 to 15 minutes.
steps.description: As soon as the soup comes to a boil, reduce the heat to a simmer over low heat. Cover the saucepan with a lid. Allow the soup to cook for 10 to 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Add the pancetta.
steps.description: Once the soup is done heating, take it off of the stove. Stir in the sautéed pancetta. Give the soup a taste, then add some more salt and pepper, if needed.

steps.headline: Serve the soup.
steps.description: ladle the soup into serving bowls. Top each soup with 2 teaspoons of extra-virgin olive oil. If you want to, add a sprinkle of grated Parmesan cheese. Serve some crusty bread on the side, if desired.
